title: What happens if you guess? - Leigh Nataro

multiple-choice.question: Which area of mathematics is used to make predictions in sports, determine the odds for who will win the Super Bowl, and set auto insurance rates?
If you were to toss a fair coin 10 times and use it to choose the answers on a true/false quiz, what is the probability of getting a perfect score by guessing?
How many different combinations of Ts and Fs can be written down for a 10-question true/false quiz, assuming each question has two possible answers?
According to the fundamental counting principle, if there are A possible outcomes for one event and B possible outcomes for another event, then how many ways are there to pair the outcomes?
What is the number of possible outcomes for a 10-question true/false quiz, where each question has two possible answers?
What is the average score you would expect to get by randomly guessing on a 10-question true/false quiz, assuming each question has two possible answers?
If there are 20 questions on a standardized test and five possible answers for each question, what is the probability of getting all 20 questions correct by randomly guessing?
What is the expected number of questions you would get right by randomly guessing on a 20-question test, where each question has five possible answers?
According to the fundamental counting principle, if there are five possible outcomes for each question on a 20-question test, how many possible outcomes are there in total?
What is the most likely score for a large group of people who randomly guess on a 10-question true/false quiz?
What type of narrative is described as the "glue that connects people" and makes a story timeless and humanistic?
According to the transcript, what are the three essential components of sourcing in journalism?

options.label: A
options.text: Official sources, eyewitness accounts, and expert opinions

options.label: B
options.text: Official sources, overview sources, and unofficial sources

options.label: C
options.text: Primary sources, secondary sources, and tertiary sources

multiple-choice.question: What type of sourcing is necessary for a well-reported piece of journalism, according to the transcript?

options.label: C
options.text: A combination of official, overview, and unofficial sources

multiple-choice.question: How can a journalist ask questions that yield compelling and insightful information, according to the transcript?
What is the role of unofficial sources in providing insight and consequence to an event or trend, according to the transcript?

options.label: C
options.text: To provide the why and what it means on a soul level

multiple-choice.question: What is the importance of anecdotes in adding life to a story, according to the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: Anecdotes are unnecessary and can be skipped

options.label: B
options.text: Anecdotes are only useful for trivial stories

options.label: C
options.text: Anecdotes are essential in adding a personal touch and making a story memorable

options.label: D
options.text: Anecdotes are only useful for investigative reporting

multiple-choice.question: When is it important to convey information quickly, according to the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: When the situation is urgent and action is required immediately

options.label: B
options.text: When the situation is critical and requires careful consideration

options.label: C
options.text: When the situation is routine and can be handled later

options.label: D
options.text: When the situation is trivial and can be ignored

multiple-choice.question: What is the role of the journalist in asking questions that yield a compelling narrative, according to the transcript?

options.label: C
options.text: To ask surprising questions and regard the stories of every subject as sacred

multiple-choice.question: What is the importance of the narrative bond in connecting people, according to the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: The narrative bond is unnecessary and can be ignored

options.label: B
options.text: The narrative bond is only useful for trivial stories

options.label: C
options.text: The narrative bond is essential in making journalism memorable and connecting people to each other

options.label: D
options.text: The narrative bond is only useful for investigative reporting

multiple-choice.question: How does the journalist achieve the complicated, fragile human connection, according to the transcript?

options.label: C
options.text: By asking surprising questions and regarding the stories of every subject as sacred

title: How fiction can change reality - Jessica Wise

multiple-choice.question: Who said that "There is no frigate like a book to take us lands away"?
According to the transcript, what is one of the effects of stories on a person's point of view?
In the novel "Pamela", what is the social status of the main character?
What is one of the lessons that novels like "Pride and Prejudice" and "Pamela" teach?

options.label: A
options.text: That marriage for love is a bad idea

options.label: B
options.text: That class and not hard work decide a person's worth

options.label: C
options.text: That women are inferior to men

options.label: D
options.text: That social class is not the sole determinant of a person's worth

multiple-choice.question: How did novels like "Pamela" challenge societal norms when they were first published?

options.label: A
options.text: They reinforced the idea that class determines a person's worth

options.label: B
options.text: They suggested that women are inferior to men

options.label: C
options.text: They presented a poor, serving-class heroine as superior to her upper-class suitor

options.label: D
options.text: They advocated for the abolition of marriage

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what are some of the characteristics of a hero in Darwin's theory of evolution?
What is one possible limitation of Darwin's theory of evolution, according to recent studies?

options.label: A
options.text: It doesn't take into account the role of chance

options.label: B
options.text: It doesn't consider the role of competition

options.label: D
options.text: It overlooks the importance of social class

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, how might our understanding of heroism be changing?

options.label: A
options.text: We are moving towards a more individualistic understanding of heroism

options.label: B
options.text: We are recognizing the importance of cooperation and shared quests

options.label: C
options.text: We are emphasizing the role of physical strength in heroism

options.label: D
options.text: We are dismissing the idea of heroism altogether

multiple-choice.question: What approach does the author suggest readers take when reading classic novels?

options.label: B
options.text: Travel with the characters and authors, while considering the changing social context

multiple-choice.question: What is one possible effect of reading "Hunger Games" on a reader's perspective?

options.label: A
options.text: It makes them more supportive of capitalism

options.label: B
options.text: It teaches them that the individual should always put themselves before the group

options.label: C
options.text: It leads them to think about capitalism in a new way

options.label: D
options.text: It reinforces their existing views on social class

multiple-choice.question: What theme does the novel "Uglies" explore?

options.label: A
options.text: The dangers of pursuing a perfect body

options.label: C
options.text: The role of social media in shaping beauty standards

options.label: D
options.text: The impact of technology on relationships

multiple-choice.question: What does the author encourage readers to do in terms of reading and writing stories?

options.label: C
options.text: Try on new stories and write their own

multiple-choice.question: What mathematical concept is used to simplify calculations involving extremely small or large numbers in various fields, including chemistry and computer science?
In the equation b^p = n, what is the relationship between the exponent p and the logarithm of n?

options.label: A
options.text: The exponent p is the logarithm of n

options.label: B
options.text: The number n is the logarithm of p

options.label: C
options.text: The base b is the logarithm of n

options.label: D
options.text: The power p is the logarithm of b

multiple-choice.question: What is the value of log base 10 of 10,000?
What is a primary application of logarithms in various fields, including chemistry and computer science?

options.label: B
options.text: To deal with extremely small or large numbers

options.label: D
options.text: To find the square root of a number

multiple-choice.question: Why is it essential to understand logarithms, even if a calculator can compute them?

options.label: A
options.text: Because it helps with mental math

options.label: B
options.text: Because it's a fundamental concept in mathematics

options.label: C
options.text: Because it's used in various real-world applications, such as computer science and chemistry

options.label: D
options.text: Because it's a requirement for a math test

multiple-choice.question: What is the formula for calculating pH levels in chemistry?

options.label: B
options.text: pH = negative log base 10 of H+

multiple-choice.question: What is the pH of water with a hydrogen ion concentration of 0.0000000398?
Why do tears in our eyes feel itchy and red when exposed to a pH of 8.4?

options.label: C
options.text: Because it's the normal pH of tears

multiple-choice.question: How can logarithms be used to find the pH of water samples?

options.label: B
options.text: By using a calculator to compute log base 10

options.label: C
options.text: By using a chart to look up pH levels

options.label: D
options.text: By using a formula to calculate pH

multiple-choice.question: What is a key benefit of understanding logarithms in computer science?

options.label: C
options.text: It helps with understanding base 2 and other number systems

title: The history of keeping time - Karen Mensing

multiple-choice.question: What is the earliest known device used for telling time, with archaeological evidence dating back nearly 5,000 years?
In a sundial, what object casts a shadow to indicate the time?
What is the primary limitation of sundials that makes them impractical for use during certain periods?

options.label: D
options.text: They are affected by temperature changes

multiple-choice.question: Which device measures time by the flow of fine sand through a small hole at a constant rate?
What was the primary advantage of using hourglasses on ships, particularly during the 14th century?

options.label: A
options.text: They were more accurate than other time-measuring devices

options.label: B
options.text: They were less affected by the motion of the boat

options.label: C
options.text: They were cheaper than other time-measuring devices

options.label: D
options.text: They were more portable than other time-measuring devices

multiple-choice.question: What is the basis for scientific time today, providing a consistent and accurate measurement of time?

options.label: A
options.text: A continuous count of seconds based on atomic clocks

options.label: C
options.text: The vibration of a quartz crystal

multiple-choice.question: Why is keeping track of time essential for modern society?

options.label: A
options.text: It regulates our daily lives and enables accurate communication with people worldwide

options.label: B
options.text: It is necessary for farming and social structures

options.label: C
options.text: It is required for business and transportation

options.label: D
options.text: It facilitates global coordination and scheduling

multiple-choice.question: What term refers to a region on Earth with a uniform standard time, helping to facilitate global communication and coordination?
How many time zones are there on land, helping to organize and synchronize time across the globe?
What is the approximate time difference between New York and Boston, highlighting the importance of time zones in coordinating schedules?
